Sorry for this late comment, but at the moment we have the odd situation where the code modifies `self.include_dirs` and then replaces it.  Would this not be clearer as:

```
        # Ensure include dirs and distribution.include_dirs are lists
        incl_dirs = self.include_dirs or []
        if isinstance(incl_dirs, str):
            incl_dirs = incl_dirs.split(os.pathsep)
        if self.distribution.include_dirs is None:
            self.distribution.include_dirs = []
        # Make sure self.include_dirs is same list as self.distribution.include_dirs
        self.include_dirs = self.distribution.include_dirs
        self.include_dirs.extend(incl_dirs)
```

comments.body: Is it necessary to change the folder name as part of this fix? I know of at least one library that has `extra-dll` hard-coded in its own `__config__.py`-like script. Keeping the old name would not break those cases.
Sorry for not getting this right the first time, but this should have been named `.libs` to begin with as  auditwheel does because it serves the same function.
If this change goes in, it needs a compatibility entry in the release notes.
@letmaik What library is that? It worries me that such things are out there.
This section seems new in 1.14, so there is still time time to change it. @pv thoughts?

As far as scipy is concerned, this doesn't matter and does not introduce extra work. I'm not sure if trying to match auditwheel is a strong argument as the name is quite arbitrary (as long as it is not a valid name for a subpackage), but maybe using same name makes it easier for downstream repackagers (pyinstaller?) etc.

This is an implementation detail that should not be relied on because `__config__.py` is the public API. Perhaps this should be clarified in the docs but this was not done in SciPy and it therefore has no effect on SciPy.

There seems to be quite a bit out there: https://github.com/search?q=extra-dll&type=Code&utf8=%E2%9C%93. Ignore the `NCAR/wrf-python` repo, this was a fix brought in by myself and I can change it easily if necessary.
Doesn't matter because this was not yet released. We  cannot guarantee API stability in the development branch -- that's unreasonable.
OK nevermind, didn't realize this was a new thing, go for it then. :)
